citations.narrative:
During the review of paperwork and records it was noted that the acquisition and disposition records were incomplete.
The facility representative did not have access to any of the acquisition and disposition records for any animals other than
a single parakeet.
Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals, and complete and accurate records of disposition are essential
for proper identification and necessary to track animals used in regulated activities to ensure their humane care, use, and
disposition.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records of acquisition and disposition for all regulated animals, including
animals born on the premises, and assure that all records are kept as required. To be corrected by the next relicense
inspection.

The walls of the outdoor aviary are made of a wooden frame with heavy gage wire panels, covered with a .5 X.5-inch wire
mesh. A portion of this wire mesh covering was rusted and broken, leaving sharp, rusty edges and protrusions.
Primary enclosures that are not kept in good repair may create hazards which can injure the birds housed within them.
Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. To be
corrected by the next relicense inspection.

Inside the bird aviary was a metal tray approximately 3 feet in length and 6 inches in width. The tray held various seeds
and foodstuff for the birds. The bottom of the tray was covered in a black, caked on layer of deteriorated feed and debris.
Failure to maintain clean food receptacles can attract pests and create an insanitary condition which may contaminate the
food within and lead to harm or disease to the birds.
Food receptacles and feeding areas must be kept clean and sanitized. Measures must be taken to ensure there is no
molding, deterioration, contamination, or caking or undesirable wetting of food within or on food receptacles. To be
corrected by the next relicense inspection.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The wall separating the two sides of the bird aviary had a wooden ledge that was covered in an excessive accumulation
of excreta and food waste. There was also a large perching branch that was covered in excessive excreta along its entire
surface.
Failure to clean accumulations of waste materials can increase disease hazards, attract insects, pests, and be a source of
odors.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from the primary enclosures and from under and from around primary
enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to reduce disease hazards,
insects, pests, and odors. To be corrected by the next relicense inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by April 29, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
During the review of paperwork and records it was noted that the acquisition and disposition records were incomplete. 
The facility representative did not have access to any of the acquisition and disposition records for any animals other than 
a single parakeet. 
 
Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals, and complete and accurate records of disposition are essential 
for proper identification and necessary to track animals used in regulated activities to ensure their humane care, use, and 
disposition.  
 
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records of acquisition and disposition for all regulated animals, including 
animals born on the premises, and assure that all records are kept as required. To be corrected by the next relicense 
inspection. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The walls of the outdoor aviary are made of a wooden frame with heavy gage wire panels, covered with a .5 X.5-inch wire 
mesh. A portion of this wire mesh covering was rusted and broken, leaving sharp, rusty edges and protrusions. 
 
Primary enclosures that are not kept in good repair may create hazards which can injure the birds housed within them. 
 
Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. To be 
corrected by the next relicense inspection. 
3.155(b) 
   
Feeding 
Inside the bird aviary was a metal tray approximately 3 feet in length and 6 inches in width. The tray held various seeds 
and foodstuff for the birds. The bottom of the tray was covered in a black, caked on layer of deteriorated feed and debris.

Failure to maintain clean food receptacles can attract pests and create an insanitary condition which may contaminate the 
food within and lead to harm or disease to the birds. 
 
Food receptacles and feeding areas must be kept clean and sanitized. Measures must be taken to ensure there is no 
molding, deterioration, contamination, or caking or undesirable wetting of food within or on food receptacles. To be 
corrected by the next relicense inspection. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The wall separating the two sides of the bird aviary had a wooden ledge that was covered in an excessive accumulation 
of excreta and food waste. There was also a large perching branch that was covered in excessive excreta along its entire 
surface. 
 
Failure to clean accumulations of waste materials can increase disease hazards, attract insects, pests, and be a source of 
odors. 
 
Excreta and food waste must be removed from the primary enclosures and from under and from around primary 
enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to reduce disease hazards, 
insects, pests, and odors. To be corrected by the next relicense inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by April 29, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT
